key_work.title: Spotlights: George Miller
key_work.brief_description: An Australian filmmaker and former physician. He is best known for his Mad Max franchise, whose second instalment, Mad Max 2 (1981), and fourth, Fury Road (2015), have been hailed as among the greatest action films of all time.

end.title: The Mad Max film series
end.brief_description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Mad Max’s super-powered vehicles, legendary characters and post-apocalyptic setting influenced everything from movies, manga and music videos to fashion, videogames and art, spawning enough parodies, homages and clones to fill a Thunderdome.

constellations_primary.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_primary.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

links.description: George Miller revolutionised action movies when he brought Mad Max to the screen in 1979. In the 40 years since, he’s continued to push the boundaries of filming action for the screen, blending high-octane spectacle, iconic characters and inspires storytelling.

links.description: The last Mad Max film, Fury Road, bagged six Oscars at the Academy Awards, but George Miller already has an Oscar to his name. Demonstrating his diverse approach to screen stories, the director won an Academy Award for Best Animated Feature with Happy Feet.
